item.title: Faster builds, please
item.description:
Itâ€™s been only a couple of days since Iâ€™ve started again and more things have changed over here. Iâ€™ve quickly discovered, after half a dozen deploys, about some of the inconveniences of Cloudflare Pages that people didnâ€™t seem to care enough to talk about. Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve noticed:

  1. The worker startup is painfully slow. Every time a new change hits GitHub, a new build is triggered on Pages and so a new worker must be started to actually build and release the website into the internet. And for some unknown reason, the startup process alone was taking half of the average needed time â€“ 5 to 6 minutes to run the entire pipeline and half of it was just to spin-up the VM (or container, I donâ€™t know). And this behaviour happened consistently.

  2. The installation of dependencies are mandatory. If pages detects a manifest file â€“ Pipfile, package.json, Gemfile etc â€“ it will install of itâ€™s dependencies. You simply cannot skip this. This might not sound that bad, butâ€¦

  3. Cloudflare Pages donâ€™t cache your build. No, Iâ€™m not talking about Cloudflareâ€™s CDN. Iâ€™m talking about all the node modules and other stuff generated at build time. Again, this might not sound that bad, but jekyll for instance relies on Ruby gems that binds to C code, which of course are system / arch-dependent and must be compiled every time. Having the option to specify a list of directories that must be cached between executions would greatly improve the build speed.

So??

Yes, a 5 minutes pipeline is not a lot, but it felt wasteful, so I did some changesâ€¦

  1. The build is now being made on Github Actions and the modules / packages / libs are now cacheable. The first run took 5 minutes just to install and compile all the dependencies; the subsequent ones, only 4 seconds. An entire build pipeline takes no more than a minute now.

  2. The builded files â€“ HTML pages and stylesheets â€“ have their own place now: a separate git repository.

  3. This site is not on Cloudflare Pages anymore.

The pipeline is a little more complex, but more faster (on average, 2 minutes from git push to a new site version be live on the internet). A git commit triggers the GitHub Action that builds the site and commits to the other repository, which in turn triggers Render â€“ Iâ€™ve talked about this guy last post. Render can do itâ€™s job in a little more than a minute â€“ hereâ€™s what a build outlook looks like:

Nov 25 12:19:40 AM ==> Cloning from https://github.com/caian-org/caian.org-dist... Nov 25 12:19:41 AM ==> Checking out commit 081d48b in branch master Nov 25 12:19:54 AM ==> Downloading cache... Nov 25 12:19:57 AM ==> Downloaded 5.0MB in 1s. Extraction took 1s. Nov 25 12:20:06 AM ==> Using Python version: 3.7.10 Nov 25 12:20:10 AM ==> Empty build command; skipping build Nov 25 12:20:25 AM ==> Uploading build... Nov 25 12:20:52 AM ==> Your site is live ðŸŽ‰

Where will you be next month?

I donâ€™t plan to leave Render this soon, but Iâ€™ll not make any promises. If I could strip down one more build minute by going somewhere else, I would. For now Iâ€™m overall happy with this new format / build process.

item.title: Starting again
item.description:
This project is alive once again. Last time Iâ€™ve poured energy into this, the site was still running on a self-managed nginx server at Vultr. Turns out Iâ€™m lazy and after a couple of months I gave up and deleted everything â€“ one OpenBSD and two CentOS servers.

Donâ€™t get me wrong: hosting your own shit is all fun and games, but â€“ for me at least â€“ it gets boring way too quickly. Oh wellâ€¦

On finding a new landlord

Static websites are cool again, so thereâ€™s actually a couple of options to choose from: surge, vercel, render, github pages, aws s3, netlify, digital ocean and (the winner) cloudflare pages. You can most certainly find other options, but thatâ€™s how far I got on a 15 min search.

Most of them are problematic in some way:

  • Surge is the most interesting of all: you install a node package on your system, build your website locally and upload the dist with a single command. Thatâ€™s it. No pipeline, no nothing. You can even add your own custom domain, but if you want secure (HTTPS) connections, you have to pay. 30 dollars, monthly, to be more specific. Thatâ€™s a NO for me.

  • AWS S3 has a similar approach, but the setup is more time consuming, the update (of pages) requires manual steps â€“ although you can automate that on a CI/CD service â€“ and, as always (thatâ€™s the AWS way of doing things), there are some hidden costs, such as cloudfront â€“ if you pretend to serve content over HTTPS. Not appealing, actually.

  • GitHub Pages is an old buddy that has only one friend: Jekyll. And even this good olâ€™ friend is dealt with limitations: not all plugins are allowed and you canâ€™t use anything besides Jekyll. Does your site need some help from another program? Perhaps youâ€™re planning to use Gulp, Webpack or whatever to build? Then no deal.

  • Netlify and Digital Ocean are similar in their features, limitations and price model: you can use your own domain with a free SSL certificate and bring code from GitHub with automatic builds. But they limit your monthly build time (in minutes). Netlify gives you 300 minutes per month free. Digital Ocean gives you even less: 100 minutes per month and only 1 GB of outbound data transfer.

  • Vercel is less about static websites and more about FaaS (function-as-a-service) and custom stuff like NextJS. In a way, hosting a site on vercel is similar to doing on S3: you can absolutely do it, but most people arenâ€™t, so the territory seems unfit.

  • Render and Cloudflare Pages seemed the most fit for the job: in both cases, you just connect the service to your GitHub account and the repository where the site is, provide a build command â€“ npm run build or whatever â€“ and thatâ€™s it. You can use your own domain and it will automatically be served over HTTPS. Iâ€™ve choosed the later only because Iâ€™m already using Cloudflareâ€™s DNS services. Thatâ€™s pretty much the only reason for not choosing Render. In the future, if Cloudflare introduces restrictions or even a price on their static site service, Iâ€™ll 100% be migrating to Render.

Pug, SASS, Gulp and other front-end toys

Iâ€™m no expert on this field â€“ you probably figured this out by seeing how simple this whole website is. Iâ€™ve never liked how bloated the front-end stack is and I plan to never ever work professionaly with this clusterfuck of frameworks and tooling. Despite my sincerely belief that the modern web is fucked beyond repair, it is fun to mess around and see how many different hammers I can use to hit the same nail.

Of course I could use plain HTML and CSS for the job, but why not complicate everything and introduce many different levels of abstractions on top of it? Again: I do not plan to make sites professionaly, so bodging and gluing stuff on top of other stuff is not only okay but fun in a perverse sense.

Iâ€™ve rewrote the CSS to SASS, the HTML to Pug and built a transpilation process on top of Jekyll using Gulp. Thereâ€™s a lot of Liquid templating that could be removed using Pugâ€™s features like include, extends and inline javascript â€“ that will be done another day. For the time being, Iâ€™ll say this project is stable enough to be tagged 1.0.0.

Silly additions and the future

It took me more than 100 commits over a timespan of two weeks to get to this point. Besides the new tooling and fancy abstractions, Iâ€™ve also added some actually useful features here:

  1. Blog posts now have tags and an estimated read time;
  2. The dark theme is less broken;
  3. Syntax highlighting on code block is improved;
  4. The files section is now being generated at build time.

Look how colorful it is (click here to change the theme):

def longest_repetition(string) max = string .chars .chunk(&:itself) .map(&:last) .max_by(&:size) max ? [max[0], max.size] : ['', 0] end

Thereâ€™s much yet to be done and Iâ€™m sure that Iâ€™ll broke many things in the process. If everything went accordingly, much will flourish the next year. What will flourish is another storyâ€¦ but it will. Have faith in me.
